organic_results.title: " That's a good question!" Exploring motivations for law and business school choice
organic_results.snippet: Students' accounts of their decisions to attend elite professional schools, although typically couched as preferences, actually reflect deep class-related constraints. In a sample of 79 law and business students, the author found that the majority chose their degrees for similar reasons: professional status, intellectual interest, and an upper-middle-class lifestyle. The students' explanations, which were full of uncertainty and default, upset the assumption that students carefully or consciously choose professional careers. Commitment to a particular …

publication_info.summary: D Schleef - Sociology of Education, 2000 - JSTOR
